Award.AwardTitle: PLUM RX: Researching a new pathway for bringing active science exploration to urban families

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Capitalizing on the appeal of the PBS KIDS project PLUM LANDING, PLUM RX will research and develop resources to help families and educators infuse environmental science learning into outdoor prescription programs, while ensuring they are appropriate for broad use in other informal settings. The growing outdoor prescription movement is designed to increase the amount of time children spend outside in nature. Programs are structured so that health care providers write "prescriptions" for children to engage in outdoor activity, and informal educators "fill" these prescriptions by facilitating youth and family participation in outdoor activities. There is preliminary evidence that these programs are getting kids outside, but best practices for transitioning "get outside" programs to become "get outside and learn about the environment" programs remain unidentified. PLUM RX is designed to build this knowledge and create resources that are responsive to the needs of both English and Spanish-speaking urban families. The project will work with informal educators and families through multiple cycles of implementation and revision, testing and refining PLUM LANDING resources (animations, videos, games, hands-on science activities, and support materials for informal educators and families), with the goal of designing an effective and accessible PLUM RX Toolkit for national dissemination. This project is funded by the Advancing Informal STEM Learning (AISL) program, which seeks to advance new approaches to, and evidence-based understanding of, the design and development of STEM (Science, Technology, Engineering, Mathematics) learning in informal environments.

The proposed research is designed to ensure that the PLUM RX Toolkit--the resources and support materials--will meet the needs of educators working in non-specialized urban settings. Education Development Center (EDC) and WGBH developers will collaborate on design-based research at three urban outdoor prescription programs serving low-income families: Philadelphia Nature Rx in Philadelphia, PA; Outdoors Rx in Boston, MA; and Portland Rx Play in Portland, OR. Moving through cycles of implementation, observation, analysis, and revision, the research team will work closely with educators, families, and developers to determine how the programmatic and structural features of the learning environment, the actions of the educators, and the intervention itself can most effectively support children and families' outdoor exploration in urban contexts. Toolkit materials will include resources for kids and families (including Spanish-speaking families) and informal educators (including those who work with families and directly with children in out-of-school settings). Directors from the three urban outdoor prescription programs will contribute to every phase of the research process, including recruiting families and youth who will participate in a weekly sequence of activities. The overarching focus of the analysis process will be on systematically describing the interaction between two dimensions of implementation: What happened during pilot implementations, and the factors that constrained or supported implementation as planned; and the quality of what happened, which will be defined with reference to the intended impacts. EDC will use a structured descriptive coding process to analyze the qualitative evidence gathered through interviews and observations during design and testing periods. Products of the research activities will include: a series of formative memos to the development team; a report mapping changes made to PLUM RX Toolkit materials in response to formative input and the intended impact of those changes; and findings regarding commonalities and differences across sites in the interaction of local contextual factors and the implementation success of the PLUM RX Toolkit. Concord Evaluation Group (CEG) will provide independent, summative evaluation of the project. Through this process, PLUM RX will build broader knowledge about how to design educational resources, geared for both families and informal educators, which respond to the unique challenges of exploring environmental science in urban environments.

POR.DRECONTENT:
PLUM LANDING: Explore Outdoors

PLUM LANDING: Explore Outdoors (formerly called PLUM RX) is a media research project that was designed to create innovative opportunities to bring environmental science learning to the hard-to-reach audience of urban families. The project capitalized on the appeal of PLUM LANDING −an NSF-funded PBS KIDS project that uses media and hands-on activities to motivate 6- to 9-year-old children to investigate nature−in order to research and develop new resources that help educators infuse active, outdoor science learning into youth and family programming in urban communities.

 

Over the course of the five-year project, media developers from WGBH and researchers from EDC partnered with outdoor prescription programs (community programs in which health care providers write "prescriptions" for outdoor activity, and informal educators "fill" these prescriptions by facilitating participation in outdoor activities) to develop an implementation model and set of resources using an iterative research and design process. The project team went through multiple cycles of implementation and revision to create the PLUM LANDING Explore Outdoors Toolkit, which consists of digital media resources (animated stories, live-action videos, a digital game, an online badging system, and an app for families), along with hands-on science activities and support materials for parents and caregivers, educators, and program directors.

 

Once the Toolkit was completed, it was distributed nationally to outdoor prescription programs, urban park and recreation programs, environmental education organizations, and other informal education groups. The project's summative evaluator, Concord Evaluation Group, assessed the experiences of our partners in using and promoting the PLUM LANDING Explore Outdoors Toolkit, and also examined the use and impact of the Toolkit among families. At the end of the project, the team shared what it had learned about the challenges facing informal educators in urban environments, and how digital media can best be designed, supported, and disseminated so that it is useful and relevant for educators and caregivers seeking to support outdoor exploration and STEM learning among urban children and families.

 

Major project outcomes were:

  1. Development of a new pathway for bringing active environmental science exploration to urban families. In creating the Toolkit, the project team worked with urban, outdoor-based programs like athletic leagues, park and rec programs, and outdoor prescription programs. We found that these programs were receptive to promoting STEM learning alongside physical fitness, and were successful in fostering science exploration among the children and families they serve, thus opening a new pathway for science exploration.

  2. Expansion of PLUM LANDING's media library to include assets that support urban families' engagement in active environmental science exploration. WGBH created a range of media resources, hands-on activities, and educator and parents supports designed to inspire and engage urban kids and families in active, outdoor nature exploration. The materials are available collectively as the PLUM LANDING Explore Outdoors Toolkit for those who want to implement the entire program, and also as discrete resources for kids, parents, and educators who visit the main PLUM LANDING site. Resources include:

 

  • An introductory video
  • A "Get Started" guide
  • Animated videos highlighting urban nature
  • Three collections of hands-on activities and take-home handouts for educators working with children, educators working with families, and families exploring nature on their own
  • Digital badges that encourage families to explore and document nature
  • A digital game that highlights interdependencies among city animals and plants
  • A mobile app that offers daily outdoor nature activities for families
  • Educator training videos and accompanying guide that provide practical guidance on working with kids and families
  • Parent videos and tip sheets that offer inspiration on getting outdoors

  3. Dissemination of research and evaluation findings to inform the field about the institutional circumstances and educator practices that support effective integration of digital media and environmental science content in sparking and sustaining urban families' exploration of the outdoors. WGBH and EDC worked with informal education programs to revise the Toolkit over several rounds of research and development. Once the Toolkit was complete, EDC created a summary of its research, laying out a set of design principles that guided the development of the Toolkit and key findings about the ways in which the integration of the design principles served to support urban children's engagement in informal, active, outdoor environmental science learning. This report, entitled "Building Broader Knowledge: Supporting Children's Active, Outdoor Science Exploration in Urban Environments," was posted to informalscience.org, and also formed the basis for several articles, webinars, and conference presentations.

 

In addition, the project's summative evaluator, Concord Evaluation Group (CEG), examined the use and impact of the Toolkit among families, both in facilitated programs and at home on their own. CEG's summative evaluation contributed to broader knowledge about the program characteristics and parent practices that can support children's outdoor science exploration in family homes and neighborhoods. One article based on this evaluation has been published in Afterschool Matters, and another is under review.
